description.narrative: The aim of this programme is to support the Government of Sierra Leone (GoSL) to reduce maternal, neonatal and under-5 mortality and morbidity by increasing utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH) services. This will be achieved through a multifaceted approach to strengthen quality, expand access, and build the demand for RMNCAH services in Sierra Leone.

activity-date.narrative: CUAMM- DOCTORS WITH AFRICA UNITE FO SEV LAYF NA SALONE – ACTIVITY SUMMARY QUARTERLY REPORT QUARTER FOUR – OCTOBER – DECEMBER, 2019 MAIN ACTIVITY COMPLETED DURING THE QUARTER ACHIEVEMENT • Coordination of health partners meeting • Six health coordination meeting was done this quarter in both districts. • Support to PUH In charges Meting • Five PHU staff in-charges meeting was done this quarter, 3 in Pujehun and 2 in Bonthe. Data presentation done in Pujehun in the meetings were on live birth at the facility Vs live birth weighed within 24hrs, ANC 1&4, Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) 1st dose & Long-Lasting Insecticides Net (LLIN) given at ANC and vaccination coverage per chiefdom. Bonthe had data presented on BCG vaccination vs live birth and uptake of vitamin A and deworming for children. • Maternal death Investigation • Nine and ten maternal deaths were investigated and reviewed in Bonthe and Pujehun this quarter. In Bonthe, ten deaths were reviewed, of those one was classified as “accidental”, due to drowning, so not considered a direct maternal death under ICD 10 classification. • Maternal deaths review Meetings completed with action points • Pujehun had 10 maternal deaths reviewed and Bonthe had nine that were reviewed. • Regarding action points, 17 action points were developed during review meetings in Bonthe and 34 in Pujehun. Eight were reached on due set, and 3 were unable to be reached on due date in Bonthe, 7 are pending. Pujehun achieved 14 action points by set due date. • Support to development of standard operating procedures (SOPs) • Human resource and Maintenance SOP were not developed this quarter as the hospital management lacks the adequate skills and time to develop the SOPs in time. CUAMM is closely following up and supporting them to develop the aforementioned SOPs in a shortest possible time. • Non-financial incentives for best performing health facilities on a pre-agreed criterion with the DHMT • Non-financial motivation awards for hard working facility and staff was done in Bonthe and Pujehun. Presentation was done to 5 best performing PHUs that proved best in four criteria set up by DHMT. • Integrated Supportive supervision and other supervisions • Two Integrated Supportive Supervision Visits (ISSV) with check list was conducted in October in Bonthe and in December in Pujehun. 60 PHUs representing (92%) out of 65 PHUs was reached in Bonthe. In Pujehun, all 84 PHUs were visited. • Support to Pediatrics and obstetric referrals • Obstetric and pediatric referrals done from SLiSL facilities this quarter include; 33 obstetric and 19 pediatric in Bonthe. And 50 and 71 in Pujehun for obstetric and pediatric referral respectively. Referrals done through the boat ambulance in the riverine include 48 for Bonthe and 21 for Pujehun. • This Quarter, a new harmonized referral form was developed by Ministry of Health and Sanitation, WHO and its health partnenrs for pilot countey wide in SLiSL II faciliries. . This quarter CUAMM planned a training to roll out national referral forms to the selected SLiSL facilities but did not happened as there were challenge with trainers from national point of view. The training is planned to be conducted in next quarter. CUAMM have printed out national referral forms and register that will last for 3 months for its SLISL facilities • RMNCHA and EmONC trainings conducted • This quarter, second batch of MCHAide training on RMNCHA topics for 91 PHU staff and 9 Hospital staff on Antenatal care(ANC), Partograph and Post Partum Haemmorage(PPH) through using small groups cluster methodology at chiefdom level started in December in Pujehun and will end in Januaury 2020. • Training for 14 CHO chiefdom supervisors from DHMT and 4 midwives on ANC, postnatal care (PNC) and PPH, Eclampsia and Mannual Vacum Extraction was done end of October 2019 in Pujehun. In Bonthe, 2 days Refresher Training on ETAT was successfully completed for 4 out 5 staff from the 5th-6th December 2019 • Mentorship on EmONC and IMNCI • Mentorship program started in full gears this quarter after all training and assessment were completed in the past quarter. This time none mentees are competent yet (85%) set as competent level after assessment. After the base line assessment, the second assessment was done in December but need to be analysed to determine the which mentee is reached the 85% competence test. • 12 facility in Bonthe and 16 in Pujehun benefited from mentorship this quarter. One mentee dropout in November in Bonthe. • Blood Donation Activities Supported • This quarter, Bonthe and Pujehun had 100% and 97% of blood representing minimum amount of blood needed on a daily basis in the hospital that will serve the district population throughout the three months. Family replacement and community voluntary drive was done to mobilise blood for the blood bank in the hospitals this quarter. In Pujehun 138 and Bonthe 102 units was collected through its blood donation drives. • DHMT/Hospital Operation support • Printing of 500 pieces each of maternity and pediatric record booklet for clients in Pujehun and Bonthe & 500 pieces of pediatric record booklet in Bonthe. And ANC books for PHUs in Bonthe • Transportation of 70 hospital beds & Mattresses and medical consignment from Freetown medical stores to Bonthe Island for Maternity and pediatric units of Bonthe government Hospital • Supported 2 annual stake holder’s coordination meeting for both Pujehun and Bonthe with attention on Maternal death, child health and drugs peddling in regards to pregnant women • Flexible fund supports • Supported DHMT with Maternal and Child health week launching and implementation in Bonthe • Support to maintenance one boat engine belonging to the DHMT in Pujehun to facilitate supportive supervision and distribution activities in riverine communities of Pujehun. • Support DHMT to the commemoration and launching of World Aids day in both districts • Others Activities completed • Chiefdom level CHO Supportive Supervision was done in 7 SLiSL Chiefdom in Pujehun and 5 in Bonthe. CUAMM supported two monthly CHO supervision in Bonthe and one in Pujehun. • Montrose and national blood bank joint monitoring, supervision and data collection visit to saving lives activities in Pujehun. • SLiSL partners (CUAMM MSSL and Restless development) in collaboration with DHMT completed one joint monitoring visit with checklist to seven SLiSL supported facilities this quarter. • One meeting was done between CUAMM and DHMTs & Hospitals management of both district this quarter to discuss the SLiSL program progress so far as the 2019-year end. Discussion was based on activity progress update and financial update of 2019.
